step.context: \text{Does the following table accurately capture}\\ \text{what we know about f(x)?}
step.reason: \text{For }x\lt 1, f(x) = x^2 + 1\text{ (parabolic curve).}\\ \text{For }x\gt 1, f(x) = x+1 \text{ (straight line).} \\ \text{Either way, f(x) is continuous for }x\neq 1.\\ \text{The only problem point could be }x = 1\\ \text{where the two curves meet - or don't meet.}

step.context: \text{What will be the condition for}\\ \text{continuity at }x=1 ?
step.reason: \text{For a function to be continuous at a point}\\ \textbf{two conditions}\text{ must be satisfied}\\ \begin{tabular}{l|c} \hline \text{In English} & \text{Mathematically} \\ \hline \text{The function must approach} & \\ \text{the same value from the left } & \\ \text{and the right} & \lim_{x\to a}f(x)\text{ exists.}\\ \text{And that value should be} & \\ \text{equal to the value of the} & \\ \text{function at that point} & \lim_{x\to a}f(x) = f(a) \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \text{This also means that wherever a function is}\\ \text{continuous, it can be drawn without lifting}\\ \text{the pencil.}
\text{Be careful about which f(x) to use when}\\ \text{calculating the left- and right-hand limits.}\\ \text{For }x\geq 1, f(x) = x+1.\text{For }x\lt 1, f(x) = x^2+1.
